H0.text: when does the sa node begin electrical signaling. Automatically

H1.text: when does the sa node begin electrical signaling. Periodically

H2.text: when does the sa node begin electrical signaling. In response to stretch

H3.text: when does the sa node begin electrical signaling. spontaneously

A4.text: Immediately after repolarization, the membrane potential of these cells begins to depolarise again automatically, a phenomenon known as the pacemaker potential.

A5.text: In a healthy heart, the SA node continuously produces action potentials, setting the rhythm of the heart (sinus rhythm), and so is known as the heart's natural pacemaker.

A6.text: Electrical signals arising in the SA node (located in the right atrium) stimulate the atria to contract.

A7.text: If the SA node fails to initialize, the AV junction can take over as the main pacemaker of the heart.

A8.text: The SA node spontaneously generates action potentials.
